p: Beyond the interesting presence of proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates, M. oleifera seeds (Table 1) contain vitamins A and B1 (Mbah, Eme, & Ogbusu, 2012). They are also sources of minerals, micronutrients, and bioactive compounds such as flavonoids, saponins, sterols, phytates, and trypsin inhibitors. The seed could be considered as oilseeds from its lipid content varying from 13% to 46%. This presents M. oleifera seeds not only as a protein source but also as a source of lipids and fibers (Compaoré, Nikièma, Bassolé, Savadogo, Hounhouigan, et al., 2011; Compaoré, Nikièma, Bassolé, Savadogo, Mouecoucou, et al., 2011).
